descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Though borders, particularly those delimiting different nation states, often appear as fixed and self-evident, the areas surrounding them?borderlands?often reveal their fluidity, porousness, and openness to change. This course engages with the concept of borderlands, broadly defined, and all the ways that language works to define what is constituted by a border, delimit what belongs and does not, and negotiate identities that span multiple "sides" of a border. It engages with both the kinds of borders that appear on maps, as well as those that become apparent only through lived experience, interrogating the ways that language discursively constructs both these boundaries and the identities of those people whose come to be defined by them. Themes include transborder migration, diaspora, and lived experience; urban borderlands related to class and race; intra-national borders and ethnicity; border conflicts; and discourses of borders and security. Geographically this course considers borders in North and South America, the Caribbean, Asia, and the Middle East.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
Students will be able to
1. understand human diversity and similarity
2. identify characteristics of borders and borderlands
3. understand key topics and methodological approaches in linguistic anthropology
4. understand the relationship between language, identity, class, race, gender, ethnicity, etc.
5. enhance their creative, critical, and informed thinking about language and culture
6. engage with the significance of theoretical debates regarding borderlands and language
